p: The effects of the decline in sea-ice on the abundance and demographic parameters of ice-associated pinnipeds had been well documented for some species, such as the Pacific walrus ( Odobenus rosmarus) [ 5], and the ringed seal ( Phoca hispida) [ 6], but climate change impacts on land-breeding pinnipeds is less well known. It has been suggested that a reduction in sea-ice could result in an increase in available coastal habitats of these species, allowing them to extend their distribution ranges toward the poles [ 7]. Alternately, the expected warmer climates could limit both range expansion and population growth because elevated air temperatures produce thermal stress and increase pup mortality [ 7].
